comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Brisbane City Hall experts should be able to fix an earliest date...the City Hall clock tower appears to have been completed in early 1930...there's a pic among this lot which I'd assume was taken in February 1930. It shows scaffolding still in place at the very top of the tower - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article21495887 ; Can't quite see the clock faces in this pic, but maybe that's due to sub-tropical haze. The Brisbane River isn't a patch on Sydney Harbour, but it's nonetheless quite beautiful in its own right (when not in flood)...throughout much of the 20th century the locals treated it as little more than a drain...thankfully that's now largely a thing of the past.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] what other pic were you referring to? That would be a great indication for the date! You're right about the river quasymody! :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/21495887 the pic of the City Hall tower with scaffolding still in place is in the montage of Brisbane clock towers...pic 2nd from right, bottom row...but the more I think about it, we can't really assume that the newspaper pic of the clock tower was taken in February 1930...I tend to think it would have been the most recent pic of the clock tower in the Brisbane Courier's photo library...but that's not the same thing.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Ah yes, I thought you meant a photo from our collection :) Yes you are right though, that's a good point.
